title: MLB playoffs: Cardinals look lifeless in ugly NLCS vs. Nationals
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: From the nation's capital, Gabe Lacques details the Cardinals' confidence after going down 2-0 and how the Nationals are using a special six to hide their fatal flaw. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – They will show up for Game 4 of this National League Championship Series, because technically, they’re still alive, and because compete is what they do, and it’d certainly be bad form if the the Washington Nationals moved on, unopposed, to their first World Series berth.

But right now, the St. Louis Cardinals’ NLCS appearance has been in name only – a disappearing act at best and, at worst, one of the all-time most futile offensive showings in postseason history.

Combine their 8-1 defeat in Game 3 on Monday night at Nationals Park with their 2-0 loss in Game 1 and 3-1 defeat in Game 2 and these Cardinals own a most dubious mark: Fewest runs scored through three games of any League Championship Series.

ROBLES: Nationals' young CF comes through in return from injury

ALCS: After spurning Yankees in 2008, Gerrit Cole can break hearts again

In fact, you have to go back to the 1966 World Series for any team to match the Cardinals’ three-game futility in a best-of-seven series.

That year, the Baltimore Orioles held the Los Angeles Dodgers to two runs in a four-game sweep, and Dave McNally and Jim Palmer are still celebrated for it to this day.

No doubt, Nationals starters Anibal Sanchez, Max Scherzer and Stephen Strasburg may one day be as revered for their performance in this NLCS as those Orioles are for their exploits then.

But we’ll have time to memorialize these Nationals. Let’s ponder, for a moment, these Cardinals and their ignominious place in history.

They’ve been blanked in 25 of 27 innings this series, and the lone runs came thanks to Nationals missteps – a line drive center fielder Michael A. Taylor misjudged into a double in the eighth inning of Saturday’s Game 2, and a slip-and-fall followed by a bad throw left fielder Juan Soto that enabled an unearned run to score in the seventh inning of Monday’s Game 3.

Yadier Molina looks on from the dugout during the Game 3 loss. (Photo: Tommy Gilligan, USA TODAY Sports)

Did an NLCS appearance really happen if you never took a lead?

Unless they flip the script on dominant lefty Patrick Corbin in Tuesday’s Game 4, the Cardinals may find out.

“We’ve got to get the lead. We’ve got to get a lead at some point in this series,” said manager Mike Shildt, who was merely stating the obvious but also can be excused for that sin in his hour of desperation. “Hard to win a game if you can’t get the lead.

“We’ve got to play with a lead.”

Baby steps: The Cardinals rapped out seven hits in Game 3, this after getting no-hit for 7 ⅓ innings by Sanchez in Game 1, and for six innings by Scherzer in Game 2.

But it’s hard to score with a nonexistent top of the order. Leadoff man Dexter Fowler struck out three times against Strasburg – on three, four and three pitches – and is 0 for 11 with six strikeouts in the series.

No. 2 hitter Kolten Wong is 0 for 10.

No. 3 hitter Paul Goldschmidt broke up Scherzer’s Game 2 no-hitter, but beyond that – hitless in his other 11 at-bats, with four Game 3 strikeouts.

“It starts with me,” says Goldschmidt, who slugged 34 home runs this season. “I haven’t really done anything this series and the results speak for themselves, especially tonight.

“Two runs in three games – it’s tough to have a lead. Our pitchers have done well. (Game 3 starter) Jack (Flaherty) did well. It’s tough to keep doing that when you don’t have the support.”

It’s hard to believe this is the same team that scored 10 first-inning runs and 13 in all to snuff the Atlanta Braves out quickly in Game 5 of the NL Division Series, sending the Cardinals home to start this NLCS with significant confidence.

But there is no Mike Foltynewicz in this series.

“It’s definitely better pitching than the Braves,” said Cardinals outfielder Jose Martinez, who has four of the Cardinals’ 11 hits in the NLCS, and will earn a second start in Game 4. “They are three of the best pitchers in the big leagues.

“Of course, you have to go out there and do your best to try to hit the ball.”

And therein lies the rub: Sanchez is really good, Scherzer a future Hall of Famer and Strasburg now sports a 1.10 career postseason ERA, with 57 strikeouts to five walks in 41 innings.

Yet at some point, you have to compete, right?

“As we tip our hat,” says Shildt, “we’ve also got to say that we didn’t expect to have scored two runs in three games by any stretch of the imagination. Like I said, we respect our opponent.

“But by no means did we have anywhere close to the expectation that we would be pretty much shut down.”

Tuesday, they’ll face Corbin, who gave up no earned runs and struck out 11 in a September start at Busch Stadium. Shildt says there “is no concession speech” being given, though Corbin may do the honors himself.

“They signed him this offseason because they expect him to be the guy he is right now,” Wong said of Corbin. “We’re a little flustered with trying to figure out how to get there, but we know how good we are.

“Once we get going, man, this team, we steamroll.”

Right now, they’re merely flattened.
description: St. Louis has managed just two runs through the first three games of the NLCS and find themselves in a 3-0 hole.
